PHONOGRAPHY

Field-recordings by bruine beer - vuilbak

Caged birds

Birds in small cages, city center of Ghent (Oude Beestenmarkt). Chaffinches, Bramblings and other songbirds.

(19/08/2016)

Roads

[View of the E40 highway from the bridge in Zwijnaarde (Ghent).]

Some time ago (January 2016) I started a project where I would record roads, roads of different kinds, those I pass by while living my days. Listening to and recording roads is and was a quite shocking experience. The awareness that these noises are produced constantly on a worldly scale and that they invariably are part of the everyday soundscape is baffling. However, even more overwhelming is the indifference and disinterst of people towards these noises. It is as if everyone ignores the most insane piece of avant-garde noise music of extreme duration, and above all seems not to experience irritation. The deafening noise of the highway is shamelessly filtered away by our neurological system and nobody cares about the noises he/she is producing while driving his/her car.

When we try to consider the sound an sich or try to put it in a musical context, the musicality is striking. The differences in dynamics and register as well as timbral differences impose themselves to the listener. Most peculiar are also the differences between different roads, which is the main merit of these recordings, namely the juxtaposition of different roads. The pulsating rhythym and repetitiveness of the E40 highway is in interesting contrast with the irregularity and diversity in sound observed at a roundabout of a middle sized road (Makro rondpunt (De Pinte)). Also the quality of the road, the presence of little puddles and cracks on the surface can render a total different soundscape (e.g. Langevelddreef (De Pinte)). Importantly, when considering roads in a musical context, the act of composing is reduced to choosing the moment of recording. Every other choice of recording moment will result in a new piece. In that sense, every recording of a road will remain an approximation, a captured moment of a never-ending piece.

Recording roads will also always be a kind of activist thing to do. I do not like the constant presence of roads, cars and industrial sound, despite being able to appreciate it muscially. In that sense I am glad we humans can filter away these noises, we don't have to listen to avant-garde noise music all the time. However, due to this ignorance, we are not noticing that there are almost no plces left where no cars can be heard. It always strikes me when walking in the Ghent natural reserve Bourgoyen-ossemeersen how beautiful nature (and mostly birds) and traffic violence are so intimately and sadly juxtaposed. I'm sure I will keep writing and talking about roads, cars and traffic, as they will remain present in my field-recordings unfortunately.

(14/08/2016)


123 Piano is a concept where several piano's are distributed across different city sites (in the city of Ghent). Everyone is free to play the piano's. It's a fantastic urban field-recording opportunity, putting in contrast musical sound, originating from carefully built musical instruments, with unintended noises from cars, busses and bicycles, as well as bypassing people. Interactions and relations between phonographic sound and canonical "musical" sound really fascinate me and for the careful listener, 123Piano is a fantastic case study. This recording on the Oude Beestenmarkt features two kids and their father at the piano. First the kids are fooling around, bringing forth musically very interesting pieces. Then the father plays a song (2 meisjes) of the in Ghent very famous songwriter Raymond Van Het Groenewoud, with of course fascinated kids as a result. Lastly they leave becasue their parking ticket will soon become invalid. The whole recording is made at about 6 meter from the piano, indicating the very obtrusive nature of the urban soundscape as the piano sounds far more distant and immersed in the noises from cars, construction works etc. Despite being able to appreciate the sounds of cars in a musical context, the excessive domination of car noises in the urban landscape makes me sad and sick.

On the second recording the recorder is lying on the piano. One can here me (try) playing Für Alina, a piece from the Estonian composer Arvo Pärt, and some subsequent improvisation. I am by no means a piano player, but enjoy pretending. The contrast of the heavenly music by Pärt (in all humbleness played by myself) and the brutal urban soundscape, here more distant as the recorder is closer to the piano, is intriguing.

(13/08/2016)

The word "Phonography"

Taken from Joel Smith (phonography.org)

The word "phonography" speaks to me precisely because, like "photography," it is agnostic; I mean it's factual rather than semantically loaded like "music" or "art" -- words that signal worthy ambitions and hierarchies that may, or may not, help you hear (or see) fresh. "Phonography" (translated literally) says nothing but: soundwriting. To me as a listener that means: audio "read" -- sound attended to -- for any revelations and resonances it turns up -- not only those that music knows how to handle, but the whole thing. (What does "audience" mean, after all?). Space, narrative, pain, hypnotism, temperature -- a sound's interesting dimension might be anywhere. Once you've listened to unauthored sounds in that spirit, music too sounds richer, more deeply authored (by the inventor of the drum, for example): fuller of history and space. Any time a sound is selected -- whether recorded, or just singled out ("listen!") -- attention has already transformed it.

Taken from Yitzchak Dumiel (Isaac Sterling) (phonography.org)

The simple answer is that phonography (literally "sound-writing") refers to field-recording. This entails the capture of any event that can be reproduced and represented as sound. Auditory events are selected, framed by duration and method of capture, and presented in a particular format and context, all of which distinguishes a recording from the original event during which it was captured. In this respect, phonography is analogous to any other form of recording. It is distinct from recording in general only to the extent that the capture of sound is privileged over its production. This bias reflects an attempt to discover rather than invent. Some useful analogies can be made between phonography and photography. The majority of early photographs were intended to be documentary or forensic, and many field-recordings serve these same purposes. Photographs made for enjoyment often emulated the aesthetics of more established forms of visual representation: painting and illustration. Many field-recordings also emulate aesthetics established by other media: e.g. a recording of a meadow or a souk in Cairo can be thought of as auditory equivalents of paintings or photographs; recordings are also used to present narratives similar to those typically conveyed by writing or film. Photography quickly developed beyond the cultural conventions prevalent at the time of its inception to become an endeavor preoccupied with more abstract and formal considerations (this transition can be viewed clearly in the work of photographers such as Edward Steichen and Edward Weston, or by contrasting photographs from 1900-20 with the work of Frederick Sommer and Minor White 3 decades later). A similar transition can be heard in phonography. Whereas the vast majority of field-recordings are manipulated as raw material for soundtracks and other auditory projects, and untreated field-recordings are used primarily for forensic and academic purposes, a new generation of recordists has emerged, preoccupied with the abstract and formal dimensions of captured environmental sound.

Inspirers

quiet american; phonography.org; Lieven Martens; Jacob Kirkegaard; Chris Watson;
